data.title: ESPN.com: 1999 NBA Draft: Jason Terry
data.text:
Jason Terry

Drafted by:

Atlanta, Round 1, pick 10.

EXPERT ANALYSIS

"No player's stock rose more from last year to this year than Jason Terry's. Terry has great speed in the open court, going on a straight line from point A to point B as quick as anyone in the draft. Terry can run all day without getting tired, and plays hard at both ends. He has good range on his shot, and can hit the 3 when given some time to shoot it. Terry also can get to the basket, but he does not really get his own shot.

Terry is good defensively, with good hands and a solid work ethic. He is a gambler on the defensive end, looking for steals and was perhaps the quickest defender in the Pac-10. He is slight of build and will need to add strength, but he has shown the ability to run the point, lead and pressure the ball. Terry will add a nice dimension to any team with his speed and energy on the defensive end."

-- ESPN's Jay Bilas

College: Arizona Height: 6-2

Weight: 172 pounds

Position: Guard

Age: 21 (September 15, 1977)

Birthplace: Seattle, Wash.

Career highlights

Named First Team All-America by The Associated Press as a senior

Also received First Team honors by The Sporting News

Honored as National Player of the Year by Sports Illustrated, CBS/Chevrolet and Rawlings/Basketball Times

Also a finalist for the John R. Wooden, USBWA/Oscar Robertson and Naismith National Player of the Year awards

Finished career as Arizona's all-time leader in steals with 245, placing him fourth on the all-time Pac-10 list

Finished 12th in school history with 1461 points, fifth in assists (493) and second in three point field goals made with 192

Only player in Arizona history to finish with 1,000 career points and 200 career steals

Arizona compiled a record of 103-28 in his four years

Helped team to NCAA National Championship in 1997

Teammate of Mike Bibby (Vancouver Grizzlies), Michael Dickerson (Houston Rockets) and Miles Simon (Orlando Magic) while at Arizona

College highlights

Senior

Named Pac-10 Player of the Year and an All-Conference First Team selection

Became the first player in the Pac-10 to lead the league in scoring (21.9 ppg, 14th in nation), assists (5.5) and steals (2.8) since 1989-90 (Gary Payton)

In first season as a full-time starter, notched eighth-highest scoring total in school history (635 points) and seventh highest scoring average

Scored 30 or more points in a game three times and 25 or more 12 times

Scored career high 37 points vs. Oregon

Was a three-time Pac 10 Player of the Week

Junior

Averaged 10.6 ppg in his role as sixth man and helped team to NCAA "Elite Eight." Won Pac 10 Player of the Week honors for the week of December 15 after averaging 12.0 points, 3.0 rebounds, 6.5 assists and 4.5 steals in wins vs. Baylor and Coppin State

Also recorded a double-double (10 points, 10 assists) in the Coppin State game

Had team-high 16 points at Oregon State

Shot 82.7 percent from the free throw line

Led the Wildcats in assists eight times

Sophomore

Made 18 starts and was fourth leading scorer at 10.6 ppg on NCAA champion

Also averaged 4.4 assists and 2.5 steals per game

Scored 23 points on 10-14 shooting in game at Washington

In the NCAA Championship Game vs. Kentucky, played 33 minutes and scored eight points, dished out five assists and made three steals, committing zero turnovers vs. Kentucky's vaunted press defense

Freshman

Played in all 31 of team's games and shot 15-for-26 (.577) from the three-point line

Scored 18 points vs. Oregon on sizzling 7-10 shooting while playing only 22 minutes

Was Honorable Mention Freshman All-Pac 10

College statistics
